message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Neural-Network-Based Event-Triggered Adaptive Control of Nonaffine Nonlinear Multiagent Systems With Dynamic Uncertainties
Paper Abstract: This article addresses the adaptive event-triggered neural control problem for nonaffine pure-feedback nonlinear multiagent systems with dynamic disturbance, unmodeled dynamics, and dead-zone input. Radial basis function neural networks are applied to approximate the unknown nonlinear function. A dynamic signal is constructed to deal with the design difficulties in the unmodeled dynamics. Moreover, to reduce the communication burden, we propose an event-triggered strategy with a varying threshold. Based on the Lyapunov function method and adaptive neural control approach, a novel event-triggered control protocol is constructed, which realizes that the outputs of all followers converge to a neighborhood of the leader's output and ensures that all signals are bounded in the closed-loop system. An illustrative simulation example is applied to verify the usefulness of the proposed algorithms.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Radial basis function network":

## Overview

A radial basis function network is an artificial neural network that uses radial basis functions as activation functions.(no content)The output of the network is a linear combination of radial basis functions of the inputs and neuron parameters.

## Architecture

RBF networks typically have three layers: an input layer, a hidden layer with a non-linear RBF activation function and a linear output layer.

## Applications

Radial basis function networks have many uses, including function approximation, time series prediction, classification, and system control.

## History

They were first formulated in a 1988 paper by Broomhead and Lowe, both researchers at the Royal Signals and Radar Establishment.

## Mathematical Details

The norm is typically taken to be the Euclidean distance and the radial basis function is commonly taken to be Gaussian.(no content)Gaussian basis functions are local to the center vector in the sense that changing parameters of one neuron has only a small effect for input values that are far away from the center of that neuron.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov–Schmidt reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov%E2%80%93Schmidt_reduction"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Central limit theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem"},{"title":"Lyapunov vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_vector"},{"title":"Conley's fundamental theorem of dynamical systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conley's_fundamental_theorem_of_dynamical_systems"}]

## Lyapunov Function

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

### Purpose and Applications

For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability.(no content)A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state, typically defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

### Construction

There is no general technique for constructing Lyapunov functions for ODEs, but in many specific cases the construction is known.(no content)Quadratic functions suffice for systems with one state, the solution of a particular linear matrix inequality provides Lyapunov functions for linear systems, and conservation laws can often be used to construct Lyapunov functions for physical systems.

### Related Concepts

In control theory, a control-Lyapunov function (CLF) is an extension of the idea of Lyapunov function to systems with control inputs. Additionally, a similar concept appears in the theory of general state-space Markov chains usually under the name Foster–Lyapunov functions.

Links: [{"title":"Time-triggered architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-triggered_architecture"},{"title":"Event (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystrokes"},{"title":"Time-Triggered Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-Triggered_Protocol"},{"title":"Maurice Heemels - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Heemels"},{"title":"DOM event - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DOM_Events"},{"title":"Event-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Event-driven programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_driven_programming"},{"title":"Event-driven process chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_process_chain"},{"title":"Inversion of control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inversion_of_control"},{"title":"Trauma trigger - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trauma_trigger"}]

Based on the search results, I found some relevant information about event-triggered control systems:

Event-triggered systems are a field of study within control theory, with researchers contributing to the analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems. 

The search results indicate that event-triggered control is distinct from time-triggered systems. Time-triggered systems are computer systems that execute tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, whereas event-triggered control operates on a different principle where actions are triggered by specific events rather than a fixed time schedule.

While the search results didn't provide a comprehensive definition of event-triggered control specifically, they do show it's an established area of research in control engineering. Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at the Eindhoven University of Technology, was named IEEE Fellow in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems, indicating this is an active field of academic research.

If you'd like more detailed technical information about event-triggered control methodology, applications, or theory, I'd be happy to search for more specific aspects.

Web search results for query: "Adaptive control"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

## Search Results for Adaptive Control

I found comprehensive information about adaptive control. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Core Concept

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

### How It Works

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

### Types of Adaptive Control

Direct methods are ones wherein the estimated parameters are those directly used in the adaptive controller. In contrast, indirect methods are those in which the estimated parameters are used to calculate required controller parameters.(no content)There are several broad categories of feedback adaptive control including Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) which incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance, and Model identification adaptive controllers (MIACs) which perform system identification while the system is running.

### Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control, which has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about nonlinear systems:

## Definition

A nonlinear system is defined as any system that is not linear, that is any system that does not satisfy the superposition principle. More simply, a nonlinear system is any problem where the variable(s) to solve for cannot be written as a linear sum of independent components.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear systems have several distinctive properties that differentiate them from linear systems:

- They do not follow the principle of superposition (linearity and homogeneity), may have multiple isolated equilibrium points, and may exhibit properties such as limit cycle, bifurcation, and chaos.
- One of the greatest difficulties of nonlinear problems is that it is not generally possible to combine known solutions into new solutions.

## Real-World Relevance

All real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)Examples of nonlinear differential equations are the Navier–Stokes equations in fluid dynamics and the Lotka–Volterra equations in biology.

## Analysis and Applications

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, and include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about multiagent systems:

## Definition and Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multiagent systems have several important features:

- Autonomy: agents areat least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous. Local views: no agent has a full global view, or the system is too complex for an agent to exploit such knowledge. Decentralization: no agent is designated as controlling.(no content)Multi-agent systems can manifest self-organisation as well as self-direction and other control paradigms and related complex behaviors even when the individual strategies of all their agents are simple.

## Structure and Types of Agents

Typically multi-agent systems research refers to software agents. However, the agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents can be divided into types spanning simple to complex. Categories include: Passive agents or "agent without goals" (such as obstacle, apple or key in any simple simulation) and Active agents with simple goals.

## Applications and Recent Developments

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.(no content)With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Search Results for "Neural Network Control"

I've found comprehensive information about neural network control. Here are the key findings:

### Overview

Neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence and have applications in predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, and generative AI.

### Applications in Control Systems

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence.(no content)Intelligent control is a class of control techniques that use various artificial intelligence computing approaches like neural networks, Bayesian probability, fuzzy logic, machine learning, reinforcement learning, evolutionary computation and genetic algorithms.

### Machine Learning Control (MLC)

Machine learning control (MLC) is a subfield of machine learning, intelligent control, and control theory which aims to solve optimal control problems with machine learning methods, with key applications in complex nonlinear systems for which linear control theory methods are not applicable.(no content)Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP), also known as approximate dynamic programming or neuro-dynamic programming, is a machine learning control method that combines reinforcement learning with dynamic programming to solve optimal control problems for complex systems by approximating value functions or control policies using parametric structures such as neural networks.

### Practical Example: Flight Control

One notable real-world application is the Intelligent Flight Control System (IFCS), a next-generation flight control system designed to provide increased safety for the crew and passengers of aircraft as well as to optimize the aircraft performance under normal conditions.(no content)The neural network of the IFCS learns flight characteristics in real time through the aircraft's sensors and from error corrections from the primary flight computer, and then uses this information to create different flight characteristic models for the aircraft.

Web search results for query: "Control theory"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "Control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable and compares it with the reference or set point. The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

Web search results for query: "System identification"

Links: [{"title":"System identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_identification"},{"title":"Automatic identification system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_identification_system"},{"title":"Nonlinear system identification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system_identification"},{"title":"Automatic Transmitter Identification System (television) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_Transmitter_Identification_System_(television)"},{"title":"System identification number - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_identification_number"},{"title":"Automated Fingerprint Identification System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_Fingerprint_Identification_System"},{"title":"National Animal Identification System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Animal_Identification_System"},{"title":"National Livestock Identification System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Livestock_Identification_System"},{"title":"Disc number - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disc_number"},{"title":"RNAi-Based Identification System and interference of Specific Cancer Cells - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RNAi-Based_Identification_System_and_interference_of_Specific_Cancer_Cells"}]

Here are the search results for "System identification":

## Main Definition

The field of system identification uses statistical methods to build mathematical models of dynamical systems from measured data.(no content)System identification also includes the optimal design of experiments for efficiently generating informative data for fitting such models as well as model reduction.

## Applications

One of the many possible applications of system identification is in control systems, as it is the basis for modern data-driven control systems, in which concepts of system identification are integrated into the controller design, and lay the foundations for formal controller optimality proofs. More broadly, the applications of system identification include any system where the inputs and outputs can be measured and include industrial processes, control systems, economic data, biology and the life sciences, medicine, social systems and many more.

## Approaches

System identification techniques can utilize both input and output data (e.g. eigensystem realization algorithm) or can include only the output data (e.g. frequency domain decomposition), with input-output techniques typically being more accurate, but the input data is not always available.(no content)Two types of models are common in the field of system identification: grey box models, where although the peculiarities of what is going on inside the system are not entirely known, a certain model based on both insight into the system and experimental data is constructed, though the model still has a number of unknown free parameters which can be estimated using system identification.(no content)Black box models represent the other type, where no prior model is available, and most system identification algorithms are of this type.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Feedback control system"

Links: [{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Feed forward (control) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feed_forward_(control)"},{"title":"Control loop - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_loop"},{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Open-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-loop_controller"},{"title":"Servomechanism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Servomechanism"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"}]

## Feedback Control System

A feedback control system is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller. A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

### How It Works

The system's name comes from the information path: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

### Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

A feedback control system is a control loop which incorporates feedback, in contrast to an open-loop controller. A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

### How It Works

The system's name comes from the information path: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

### Practical Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

### Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

Perfect! I have successfully completed the task. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification**: The paper "Neural-Network-Based Event-Triggered Adaptive Control of Nonaffine Nonlinear Multiagent Systems With Dynamic Uncertainties" is classified as a **contribution** paper.

**Extracted Triples**: I identified and documented 10 key triples from the paper:

1. **Adaptive control** (uses) - method for handling unknown systems and uncertainties
2. **Radial basis function network** (uses) - neural network approach for function approximation
3. **Lyapunov function** (uses) - theoretical foundation for stability proofs
4. **Nonlinear system** (uses) - core problem domain being addressed
5. **Multi-agent system** (uses) - collaborative control framework
6. **Control theory** (uses) - fundamental theoretical framework
7. **Closed-loop controller** (uses) - feedback control mechanism employed
8. **System identification** (uses) - parameter estimation for unknown dynamics
9. **Neural network** (uses) - core computational method
10. **Event-triggered architecture** (proposes) - novel communication protocol with varying threshold

All triples have been validated successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs, entity types, and relevance descriptions. The validation confirms:
- Paper Type: contribution (✓)
- 10 triples documented (✓)
- Proper distribution of entity types: 6 methods, 2 concepts, 2 tasks (✓)
- All relationships meet validation requirements (✓)
